posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked: RB707 was updated this season to allow RFID or NFC systems used exclusively within the robot. Did anyone take advantage of this? If so, what did you use it for?

posts.name: bgg
posts.cooked: I talked briefly with 5892 Energy HEROs who were using it for battery tracking.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Oh man, I'm bored and so tempted‚Ä¶

posts.name: Michelle Banas
posts.cooked: I think I remember someone bringing up battery tracking in the original update thread. That's not a bad idea, but is the robot using this data at all?
I wasn‚Äôt sure if it was a good idea or bad idea.

5892 Programmer here, my project involved NFC battery tracking designed to simplify battery selection and prevent reuse. Unlike solutions such as 6328, which use QR codes, NFC allows storing data directly on the battery, enabling usage history and tracking of Ah consumption. This data can be accessed via robot logs or scanned with a smartphone. Android users don‚Äôt need a special app, but iOS requires one. Testing confirmed functionality on a roboRIO, though this season‚Äôs execution faced issues due to a lack of training in electrical work and driver problems when integrated with a copossessor, leading to excessive loop runs. With these challenges resolved, future work may include blogging about the project.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
From a 6328 perspective, we really like having battery tracking data. In the past, we've used a QR- or bar-code scanner to log which battery is in use on the robot. This allows us to monitor any power-related performance issues tied to a specific battery, although this hasn't been an ongoing problem. Positioning the scanner has sometimes posed a challenge.  

This year, however, we decided not to pursue the QR scanner approach. Instead, we turned to RFID technology after an update was introduced. We purchased simple RFID readers and battery-friendly stickers, programmable via a phone, with the goal of achieving a direct-to-Rio RFID reader. Unfortunately, we couldn't complete this project due to competing priorities.  

Last year, we opted for the QR scanner instead because of its weight, even if we had intended to mount it. This year, we didn't use the QR scanner at all‚Äîdespite our attempts‚Äîto avoid the added weight.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Modular subsystems, such as those seen in FIRST Lego League competitions, allow for swapping components similar to what you might find in FIRST Robotics Competition setups. Specifically, in FRC, these subsystems often serve as spares.

Imagine having two identical assemblies of a subsystem but with slight variations‚Äîsuch as different CAN IDs, PIDF constants due to manufacturing differences (maybe friction-related issues...), or even swapped parts like a Talon SRX versus a Spark Max in Brushed mode. When you swap these, you‚Äôd typically need to modify your code, replacing specific blocks of functionality manually. This process introduces potential errors and can be cumbersome, especially when dealing with different motor controller vendors.

Instead, consider tagging subsystems with an RFID sticker or similar identifier. Upon startup, the RoboRIO scans these tags and selects the appropriate configuration automatically. This eliminates the need for manual code changes, reducing the chance of errors.

While this idea may seem complex, it‚Äôs definitely worth exploring. It offers a sleek solution for managing diverse configurations with minimal effort.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: The text discusses the use of robot-collected data for tracking battery metrics such as usage duration and discharge levels. While the robot does not analyze this data itself, offboarding processes can derive insights, such as designating batteries for demo duties due to excessive usage. Additionally, knowing a battery's internal model allows for setting safe current budgets to maintain operation above brownout voltages. Although this approach has potential applications, its implementation has faced challenges since its last successful application in 2016.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: So I am having something coming up. I am now making a battery tag reader with ESP32 and RC522 on CAN bus. Currently, I am waiting for parts and hope I could get it working in a week. On the picture is a design concept of reader for KOP chassis. There will be two RC522 on each side of the antenna holder (green part) so battery could be installed in any direction. Another thing working on the CAN bus! A LCD Screen! And firmware on arduino
